most yellow cake recipes turn out like
this this is pretty common it's a dense
and buttery version of a yellow cake
something that has a very tight crumb to
it lots of structure really durable easy
to cut into nice layers perfectly
acceptable however I personally like
something that has a lighter texture to
it something that has an equal amount of
flavor but it's a little bit more
delicate and not so dense and that's
this version I have here in front of me
and this is our light and fluffy version
now we're using pretty much the same
ingredients here with slight variations
in quantity or in substitutions of
ingredients but the method overall is
pretty much the same and I'm going to
show you today how to make this version
so let's get started here in a bowl of a
stand mixer with a paddle attachment I
have two sticks of unsalted butter now
in making a yellow cake it's a butter
cake so of course you need to start with
the butter and to that I'm going to add
two cups of sugar now this quantity of
butter and sugar here is going to be the
same whether or not you make the dense
version or if you're making the light
and fluffy version so you really want to
give this mixture here some time to
cream together creaming is the process
of incorporating the sugar into the
butter into the fat dissolving it
slightly and building up air it's very
important for the leavening of the cake
to allow this process enough time to do
that so this is going to take anywhere
from three to four minutes on a medium
high speed
in this recipe for the light and fluffy
version what you need to do is you need
to separate your eggs separate the yolk
from the white that's for the light and
fluffy version now if you were going to
make the dense and buttery version all
you need to do is keep the eggs together
and you're going to add whole eggs one
at a time at this point so light and
fluffy version I'm just going to add the
yolk here at this stage with the mixer
on low speed and you want to make sure
you're adding the yolks one at a time
and this is really important in cake
making you don't want to overburden the
butter sugar mixture with too much
liquid at once because what it's going
to do is it's going to break the creams
mixture here and it's going to deflate
the mixture so adding your eggs or your
egg yolks in this case one at a time is
really important
mixing after each addition
and now to this I'm going to add the
flavoring so I'm going to use about a
teaspoon of vanilla extract you could
use lemon zest here orange zest but this
vanilla really goes well with a butter
cake that you can pair with so many
different frostings or fillings and this
looks nicely combined I'm going to turn
this off and now I'm going to sift
together my dry ingredients now the
quantity of flour that we're going to
use today for this cake is the same it's
three cups regardless of the version
that you're making dense or light and
fluffy however the type of flour is
different for this version this light
and fluffy version I'm using cake flour
3 cups of cake flour and cake flour is
different than all-purpose flour and
that the protein content of the flour is
much lower it's about 7 to 8 percent for
the majority of cake flours in the
United States compared to all-purpose
flour which can be about 11 to 12
percent protein you might be wondering
what does the protein do well protein
gives strength and structure to cakes
and in this case we want less strength
and structure we don't want something so
dense and rigid we want something that's
light airy and that will ultimately give
us a really wonderful crumb to the cake
so three cups of cake flour here to that
I'm going to add a half teaspoon of salt
and now I'm going to add the lemon agent
and today I'm using a mixture of two
different leaveners so I'm using baking
powder here this is double acting baking
powder that's the most commonly sold in
the United States two teaspoons goes
right into this mix here and a half a
teaspoon of baking soda baking powder is
really unique and then it reacts in two
different stages it reacts with the
addition of moisture so when we are
going to add in our dairy it's going to
start the leavening process and also
with heat so once you put it in the oven
now baking soda on the other hand it
needs an acidic component an acidic

order for it to activate you've all done
maybe those science projects in school
where you take a little bit of vinegar
and you mix it with some baking soda and
it kind of erupts into some mess
that's kind of similar to what's going
to happen in the cake batter so I'm
sifting these dry ingredients together
using a wire whisk and so I'm just
combining the ingredients all together
I'm making sure that the leaveners are
evenly distributed so that there's no
eruptions in the cake batter in certain
spots it's leavened evenly so just
whisking this together will do just that
and so now I'm going to pass this

going to do is it's going to lighten it
the flour mixture and it's also going to
work out any clumps that we might have
now again I'm making this light and
fluffy version if you were making the

so I'm just sifting over a piece of

another tip here guys when you're using

reason I'm using buttermilk here as

is because we've added baking soda to

and add a whole nother layer of

on different layers of leavening to get
the lightest and fluffiest cake possible
so turn your machine on low speed and
you want to add your flour mixture in

going to add
a third of my buttermilk turn it down
low and you guys want to be careful here

and I'm starting and ending with the
flour that's an important tip here guys
so just mix this until it's almost a

have one last step to do to make this
the lightest and fluffiest cake batter
so now the final step is taking those
egg whites that we had reserved and

these are room temperature as are all of
the ingredients that we're using today
to make the cake you want to make sure
they all work together in a harmonious
batter so now I'm going to take these
egg whites and using a balloon whisk
here I'm going to whip these up into
soft peaks
so whipping these egg whites up to a
nice soft peak and folding them in the
batter is going to be the last step in
leavening this yellow cake what's going
to happen is all of the little air
bubbles that pockets that we're creating
in this egg white mixture are going to
expand in the oven and create a very
lofty light and fluffy cake to lighten
the batter add about half of your egg
whites and you want to fold this mixture
together so folding again you guys is
kind of coming up around the sides of
the bowl and bringing the batter up and
over the egg whites and continuing this
process and once you have some of the
egg whites incorporated and the batter
youyou kind of noticing it lighten it's
not as stiff that's when you want to add
the rest of your egg whites so all of
those egg whites so again here you're
not adding a new ingredient you're just
changing one ingredient by separating
the whites and the yolk and you
even more loft and lightning of your
cake batter so at this point you guys
you should have your oven preheated 350

it's really best to bake in the center

won't stick to the bottom of the pan and
what I like to do if you guys have a

it's not broken at all and that's
because all of our ingredients were at

gradually and we didn't overwhelm the

will bake up nice and evenly in the oven
take an offset spatula and smooth this
out into the corners of the pan and
sometimes people tell you with denser
